Maryam Kiani obtained her M.Phil. degree from National University of Science and Technology (NUST) Islamabad, Pakistan. She is currently doing Ph.D. at College of Material Science and Engineering Sichuan University China and doing research on Energy Materials and Devices under supervision of Prof. Ruilin Wang. Her research is focused on non-noble metal electrocatalyst for fuel cells. Jie Zhang received her Ph.D. degree in materials physics and chemistry from Sichuan University in 2017. She is currently a postdoctoral research associate in College of Materials Science and Engineering of Sichuan University for Energy Materials and Devices in the group of Prof. Ruilin Wang. Her main research interest is focused on the non-precious metal electrocatalysts for PEMFC applications. Yan Luo is currently a Ph.D. candidate in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. She received her B.S in Material Chemistry from Sichuan University. Her research interests are focused on the design and synthesis of no-precious electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction under supervision of Prof. Ruilin Wang. Chunping Jiang is currently a lecturer in West China School of Public Health No 4, Sichuan University. She received her Ph.D. degree in Materials Physics and Chemistry at Sichuan University in 2014. She studied in Wyoming University for 2 years as a joint Ph.D. student. Her research interests are focused on water splitting by sunlight, ORR electrocatalyst synthesis and extraction and analysis of Chinese herbs. Jinlong Fan is currently a Ph.D. candidate in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. He received his MS degree in applied chemistry from the Sichuan University of Science and Engineering in 2014. His research interests focus on the refining technology of rare metal and new energy materials. Gang Wang obtained his Ph.D. in Material Physics and Chemistry from Sichuan University in 2014. After postdoctoral research at Sichuan University, he joined the New Energy and New Materials Laboratory at College of Materials Science and Engineering of Sichuan University in 2017 as an associate professor. His current research interests are redox flow batteries related fields. Jinwei Chen is currently an associate professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. He received his Ph.D. degree from College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University in 2010. His research interests are in the areas of nanostructured functional materials and their application in sustainable energy and clean environment technologies. Ruilin Wang is a full professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. He received his Ph.D. degree from Department of Chemistry at Bath University in 1999. He worked in Oxford University, Bath University and Imperial College London as a postdoctoral research associate for 4 years. His research interests are in the areas of photoelectrochemistry and electrochemistry related fields. item S2095-4956(17)30930-0 S2095495617309300 1-s2.0-S2095495617309300 10.1016/j.jechem.2018.01.019 College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610065 China ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors. The main difficulty in the extensive commercial use of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is the use of noble metals such as Pt-based electrocatalyst at the cathode, which is essential to ease the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cells (FCs). To eliminate the high loading of Pt-based electrocatalysts to minimize the cost, extensive study has been carried out over the previous decades on the non-noble metal catalysts. Development in enhancing the ORR performance of FCs is mainly due to the doped carbon materials, Fe and Co-based electrocatalysts, these materials could be considered as probable substitutes for Pt-based catalysts. But the stability of these non-noble metal electrocatalysts is low and the durability of these metals remains unclear. The three basic reasons of instability are: (i) oxidative occurrence by H2O2, (ii) leakage of the metal site and (iii) protonation by probable anion adsorption of the active site. Whereas leakage of the metal site has been almost solved, more work is required to understand and avoid losses from oxidative attack and protonation. The ORR performance such as stability tests are usually run at low current densities and the lifetime is much shorter than desired need. Therefore, improvement in the ORR activity and stability are the key issues of the non-noble metal electrocatalyst. Based on the consequences obtained in this area, numerous future research directions are projected and discussed in this paper. Hence, this review is focused on improvement of stability and durability of the non-noble metal electrocatalyst. Graphical abstract Non-noble metals are summarized for high-electrocatalytic performance of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells; Emphasis is given to co-doped carbon supports with the different morphologies of nanoparticles and tunable pore size for high surface area. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Non-noble metal electrocatalysts Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) Electrocatalysis Stability 1 Introduction Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), which can transform chemical energy into electricity via electrochemical reactions, considered as the ideal sources for stationary and mobile applications owing to their high energy production, power density, and low emissions. Numerous tasks have been identified for commercialization of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells, which involve insufficient durability as well as high cost. Thus, durability and price seem to be the main issues for attention to effectively succeed the commercialization, the smallest lifetime requirements are 40,000 h for stationary applications which are fixed by the American Department of Energy (DOE) and around 5000 h for automotive [1]. Although, recently many efforts have been put on cost reduction and improvement in durability, still fundamental innovations in PEMFC technology are essential that can make a sustainable possible commercialization. Generally, PEMFC lifetime might be decreased by water managing system [2–6], membrane electrode assembly contamination, thermal and power cycling [7,8]. All can induce membrane electrode assembly degradation, Pt accumulation [9–15] or carbon corrosion [16–23]. On the other hand, degradation takes place under intense anomalies such as oxygen saturation through the membranes or in defective control of functioning parameters, such as reactant and fuel starvation, which leads to a process with an insufficient gas in the active layer [24–33]. Hence, the enormous struggle is made universally to understand the mechanisms of degradation to obtain the above mentioned lifetime objectives. Owing to the extensive scope of this field and the numerous review articles previously published on the impurities impact and water management [34,35], degradation mechanisms related to the Pt-based catalyst, carbon support and emphasis on fuel and oxidant starvations which was studied by researchers [36]. Furthermore, concerns about cost issue, the required quantity of the Pt in FC has drawn an extensive decreasing race from 28 mg cm−2 to 0.4 mg cm−2 or lesser amount at the cathode and 0.05 mg cm−2 at the anode [37,38]. It was obtained gradually by substituting Pt with carbon-support Pt nanostructures. Whereas, Pt catalyzes the carbon-support oxidation and carbon-support oxidation accelerates the release of sustained catalyst nanoparticles and consequently, active surface area decreased which highly effects ORR performance [39]. According to DOE's study in 2007, 56% of the cost in a PEMFC stack comes from the Pt-based catalyst layers rely on an expected cost for large-scale fuel cell fabrication [1]. These outcomes from a significant amount of Pt-based catalysts mandatory in (i) the cathode catalyst layer to catalyze the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) as well as (ii) the anode catalyst layer to catalyze the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR). Particularly, when associated to the anodic HOR, the cathode undergoes from comparatively slow ORR kinetics and consequently high overpotential, cramping the PEMFC's performance. Currently, in terms of activity and stability, Pt-based electrocatalysts considered the practical materials, even though their overall performance is still not enough and requires further development. The main problem of these Pt-based catalysts is their high cost and limited availability, paying to the too much production costs of PEMFC systems. Regarding the availability of Pt for PEMFCs, certain arguments show the significance of Pt reusing. If the Pt could be recovered at the end of the FC life with an efficiency of 100%, then Pt accessibility might not be a severe difficulty in facing FC commercialization. Though, exclusive of the progression costs of recycling Pt, the material loss for full life cycle will draw heavily on global Pt supplies owing to genuine recycle efficiencies being less than 100%. Moreover, the price of Pt has been increasing day by day. This will only assist to intensify this task facing FC commercialization. Many other noble metal-based electrocatalysts such as Pd and Ru have been studied as replacements to Pt, these metals have nominal applicability although, as it involves substituting one costly metal with alternative less expensive metal with declined activity. Therefore, emerging low-cost catalyst materials with high performance as well as durability has appeared at the front of current research and progress energies headed for PEMFC technology. For PEMFC cost reduction, the search for low-cost, high-performance catalyst for PEMFC has taken two diverse approaches. The first one approach is to lessen catalyst use by increasing Pt consumption in the catalyst coatings. This approach is feasible by Pt alloying with low-priced metals such as Co, Fe, etc., and by consuming exceptional supportive materials for the deposition of Pt nanostructures. In the previous three decades, the necessary Pt loading has been decreased considerably to about 0.4 mg cm−2 [40]. Unfortunately, the rising Pt price at this time has entirely balance the Pt loading decline, the struggles made to Pt loading reduction is ineffective in the previous decades. Thus, it appears that this approach might not be the long-lasting way out for the cost reduction of PEMFC. Another approach is the fabrication of non-noble metal electrocatalyst. This approach has been encouraged widely by the current impulse for PEMFC commercialization. So, improvement of high performance, non-noble metal catalyst appears to be the solution for a long-lasting and maintainable commercialization of PEMFCs. Unluckily, till now, the performance of the greatest non-noble metal electrocatalysts e.g. carbon supported Fe and Co-N electrocatalysts are still substandard compared to Pt-based electrocatalysts in terms of both performance and stability. However, the enhancement in both performance and stability of non-noble metal electrocatalysts towards their practical use has been realized in the current period, which makes this approach more energetic and favorable. To the improvement in non-noble metal based electrocatalysts for PEMFC technology, research struggles have been more extensive, covering a comprehensive diversity of potential materials, some of them have been revised in latest years [41–45]. The utmost feasible electrocatalysts examined, are carbon sustained M–N x /C nanocomposites, whereas M=Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, etc. designed by the pyrolysis of various metals, nitrogen and carbon precursors [46]. Many other non-noble metal electrocatalyst materials studied involve non-pyrolyzed transition metal macrocycles, conductive polymer-based complexes, transition metals, metal oxide, metal carbide, metal nitride materials, moreover enzymatic based electrode materials. For ease, catalyst performance signifies the ORR electro-kinetics, occurs on these materials, usually analyzed at the high electrode potentials. The electrochemical activity is calculated on a volumetric basis, as non-noble metal electrocatalysts are reasonably low-cost compared with Pt metal electrocatalyst. Hence, increased loading is not an important issue if catalyst layers thickness approaches to 100 mm, at that point mass transport problems will rise [40]. Electrochemical performance not simply provides a metric of the ORR electro-kinetics which occurs in a wide potential range, but it also takes into consideration mass transport, electronic transport, structural and chemical aspects rising from the diverse catalyst structures. Stability and durability of non-noble electrocatalytic materials involve the activity and performance maintenance subsequent accelerated degradation testing. Regardless of remarkable development in the field of non-noble metal catalysts for PEMFC technology, yet both the specific activity and stability needs have not been met the desired requirements. In this paper, understanding to the development of non-noble metal electrocatalysts with a diversity of several different nanostructures and properties will be delivered, accompanied by the projected catalytically active sites and reaction mechanisms for PEMFCs technology from many authors. Discussion of the issues manipulating catalytic performance as well as strategies and proposed synthesis schemes for future improvements will be provided. 2 Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) description The automotive fuel cell generates electrical energy from the electrochemical oxidation of hydrogen. It is built-up as a stack of similar repeating unit cells containing a membrane electrode assembly (MEA) in which two electrodes used as anode and cathode. Both the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and anodic hydrogen oxidation reaction occur on the platinum-based electrocatalysts surface. As the name denotes, proton exchange membrane is the main part of the fuel cell. It permits protons to pass through it almost without hindrance, whereas electrons are obstructed. Consequently, when the H2 knockouts the catalyst and splits into electrons and protons (whereas a proton is similar as H+ ion), the protons go directly to the cathode although the electrons are obligatory forced to move through the external circuit. They do advantageous work in the way such as driving a motor or lighting a bulb etc., before mingling with the protons or H+ ion and O2 to yield water on the other side. Following reactions occur in a fuel cell. 2.1 ORR in acidic conditions Pt-based electrocatalysts have exposed reasonable performance and durability for commercial applications, although it is very costly. In recent years research is emphases on scheming enhanced activity ORR electrocatalysts with prominently eliminated or reduced Pt in electrocatalyst. Numerous approaches that have been used to obtain this include the synthesis of core-shell nanostructures and shape-controlled nanocomposites to acquire facet exposure to increase the surface area that can modify the interactions with ORR intermediates. 2.2 ORR in alkaline conditions As the ORR is a simple process which provides the opportunity for non-platinum electrocatalyst alternatives, containing metal oxides, nanostructured carbon-based electrocatalysts in alkaline media. The performance of ORR on metal oxides and carbon-based nanostructured electrocatalysts are still lagging behind that of Pt. Our goal is to produce novel nanomaterial designs and develop a detailed understanding the properties of the surface structures which effect intermediate adsorption energies and ORR performance of PEMFCs. ORR in acidic electrolyte: O2 + 4H+ + 4e– → 2H2O (four electron process) O2 + 2H+ + 2e– → H2O (two electron process) H2O2 + 2H+ + 2e– → 2H2O ORR in basic electrolyte: O2 + 2H2O + 4e– → 4OH− (four electron process) O2 + H2O + 2e– → HO2 − + OH− (two electron process) H2O + HO2 − + 2e– → 3OH− 2.3 Working principle of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell Hydrogen gas (H2) is forced by the catalyst with the pressure which is inflowing the fuel cell over the anode. As the H2 molecule comes in contact with the Pt on the catalyst, it divided into two electrons (e−) and H+ ions or protons. The electrons are conducted by the anode and travel through the external circuit and then come back to the cathode. In the meantime, oxygen gas (O2) is being forced by the catalyst on the cathode, where two oxygen atoms are formed. These oxygen atoms have strong negative charge, while H+ ions attracted by these negatively charged oxygen atoms through the membrane, where they combine to form a water molecule (H2O). These reactions take place in a cell stack. The stack will be fixed in a unit containing fuel, air management, water as well as coolant control software and hardware, and then his unit will be combined with a complete system to utilize in various technology applications. Owing to the high proficiency of fuel cells (55%), this prodigious technology is beneficial in numerous applications like transport such as vehicles, forklifts, cars, buses, etc., and backup power to generate electricity in a disaster of the electricity network. Fig. 1 shows schematics of working principle of the fuel cell. 3 The elementary electrocatalyst designs 3.1 Facet sensitivity, morphological and size impact of catalyst nanoparticles on ORR performance Catalyst revealed size and morphology influence as well as facet sensitivity during ORR process; their catalytic performance and stability could be stimulated by tuning the size of particles, promising morphology and the extensive exposure of active facet. Several reports [47,48] confirmed that the electrocatalytic performance improves by the reduction of particles size, appealing that the decrease of particle size clues to narrower D-band and up-shift of D-states to Fermi level, which leads to consequences in improved catalytic performance. Lee et al. [49] reported that the catalytic activities of polycrystalline Au particles which have mean diameters of 3, 6 and 8 nm and best activity displayed by particles having 8 nm diameters that is the result of more defects in structures, which indicates that only small size is not enough for the best activity. Lee and Chiou [50] prepared Pd nanocubes with the different particle size of 27, 48 and 63 nm, whereas 48 nm Pd nanocubes show higher activity in methanol solution compared to other size nanocubes. Activities of these nanocubes have the order of 48 nm Pd > 27 nm Pd > 63 nm Pd. Numerous publications revealed the morphology effects in monometallic electrocatalysis which includes assessment among several morphologies for example nanospheres, nanocubes, nanowires, nanorods, nanobelts nanoclusters, nanoparticles and flower-like nanostructures etc. [51,52]. Lu and Chen [53] synthesized Ag particles and nanoclusters with meso-2, 3-dimercaptosuccinic acid as a defensive ligand; consequences indicate that the specific activities of nanoclusters are higher than the nanoparticles. Erikson et al. [54] elaborate that cube-shape Pd nanoparticles rose up among bulk Pd material and sphere-shaped Pd nanostructure, in the specific activities, onset and half-wave potentials, because of the availability of dominant (100) active facets in the cube-shaped nanostructure. Jin et al. described that electrochemical reduction methodology to synthesize Ag nanoclusters with single-stranded oligonucleotide sequences (ssDNA) which is allocated as the template for Ag nanoclusters. The existence of ssDNA certified the in-situ reduction of Ag+ via attaching Ag nanoclusters on the nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) surface. The consequential Ag NCs/NG nanocomposite display analogous electrocatalytic performance and higher stability to the commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst and it is interpreted as the outcome of interactions between ssDNA template, NG sheet and AgNCs nanoclusters. One more main factor is the facet desire towards the ORR catalysis, in which various dissimilar monometallic electrocatalysts demonstrate diverse facet sensitivities [45]. It motivates to modify the synthesis of electrocatalysts to acquire more active facets. It is elaborated that facets and other sites for example edge and vertex sites synchronize to their whole coordination numbers and the facets which have less atomic coordination number clue for durable oxygen binding [55]. 3.2 Extended surface area catalysts Catalysts that contain large area surfaces prolonged in two dimensions like thin films known as extended surface area catalyst (ESAC). The ORR performance of ESACs is almost ten times higher than carbon supported nanoparticles electrocatalysts in acidic media, because of the structural and electronic properties of thin films compared to nanostructures. Examples of ESACs are single-crystalline bulk material electrocatalyst or polycrystalline catalyst surfaces [56–59]. These catalysts assist as valued model systems that have shown the importance of structural aspects such as single-crystal surface alignment, size, shape, category and composition on performance. Certain progressive extended surface area alloy catalysts (ESAACs) expose a roughed surface with Pt atoms that cover the ordinary bulk composition as well as a highly coordinated ‘Pt-peel’ superimposing a controlled surface structure in which the fundamental three layers alignment fluctuates to the bulk. This kind of Pt-peel surface structure of Pt3Ni1 {111} and Pt3Co was testified to report the high performance of 18 mA per cm2 Pt almost 3–4 times higher compared to standard commercial Pt/C relative to rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements. The order of ORR activities at 60 °C was “Pt-peel ”> Pt3Co > Pt3Ni > Pt. The electrocatalytic improvement was greater in 0.1 M hydrochloric acid than that in 0.5 M sulfuric acid, with the maximum improvement detected for the “Pt-peel surface” on Pt3Co in 0.1 M hydrochloric acid, which is 3–4 times higher than pure Pt [60]. The Pt and Ni atoms arrangement in the upper three coatings of this system due to several shifts in the D-band compared to the Fermi level of the highest layer of Pt atoms, which is supposed to influence on the adsorption exposure of hydroxyl species that affect ORR activity. But still, there is further need to explore that how to obtain a practicable electrocatalyst. According to literature survey, the nanostructured thin-film catalysts (NSTFCs) are the applicable ESACs [61–64]. 3.3 Metal-ion center effect on the ORR activity and stability of transition metal macrocycle compounds The metal ion center has an important effect on the redox and electronic properties of transition metal compounds. Co and Fe metal-ion centers demonstrate the best electrocatalytic properties, ascribed to their unique redox properties and have been projected as the efficient active sites for the ORR in PEMFCs in alkaline media [65,66]. Consequently, these two specific metals have been the emphasized for the common studies in ORR non-noble metal electrocatalyst technology. The metal interaction nature plays a significant role in the ORR performance of these compounds. Predominantly, a high ionization potential of these metal-ion centers has been estimated to be a key feature that has great influence on ORR performance [67,68]. Specific research on density functional theory calculations, Co porphyrin has a much higher degree of ionization potential than their Fe supplements [69]. Although, FePc possess a considerably higher ionization potential as compared to CoPc, explaining the influence of ligand on the properties and ORR performance. Generally, for all of these explored metal-ion centers, significant ORR performance could be associated to higher ionization potentials and amplified oxygen binding capabilities. 4 Non-noble metal catalysts Pd, Pt-based electrocatalysts and Pd-based transition metal alloy electrocatalysts have been reported because of the shortage and high cost of noble metals [70,71]. Nevertheless, the dominant performances reported for Pd are hardly comparable to commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst. Anyhow, most of the Pt is substituted by Pd may not suggestively address the matter of cost, because of the variation in price and demand [72]. Non-noble metal catalysts reduce costs and have revealed intense development in ORR performance. Various approaches have been discovered for the preparation of non-noble metal electrocatalysts such as cobalt pyrolysis and iron-containing heteroatom polymer precursors etc. [72–81]. The Dodelet group's impregnation and pyrolysis synthesis route to networking of the nitrogen and Fe, has commanded to the highest activity [80–86]. The active site's nature in non-noble metal catalysts still needs to be discussed, such as the query is whether Fe is coordinated with the active site or with the resources of generating such kind of active site, catalyst durability is poorer at higher potentials and for automotive commitments, catalytic performances at less than 0.6 V are basically inappropriate. 4.1 Transition metal oxides/carbides/nitrides/oxynitrides/sulfides Even though Pt or Pt-based alloys have been developing as ORR electrocatalysts, still they are suffering from numerous drawbacks such as migration, accumulation, suspension, redeposition (Oswald ripening process), and corrosion by carbon, most notably; their high cost and accessibility are frequently highlighted as the major issue in the commercialization of FC technology. Thus non-noble metal electrocatalysts have been fascinated due to their low cost and electrocatalytic performance; however, their durability still essentially need be enhanced [87–89]. Xia et al. [90] reported a giant class of metal and nonmetal complexes, containing oxides, carbides, nitrides, as well as oxynitrides, have been gradually examined to enhance their ORR catalytic performance and stability by modifying particle size, morphology and conductivity [91]. 4.1.1 Metal oxides In the meantime, metal oxide, carbon complexes have revealed remarkable improvement in activity and durability [92]. Hence, the modification of electronic structure can lead to improved catalytic activity. Recently, metal carbides were utilized in acidic media as catalyst supports for ORR by adjustment of the D-band center to best location [93]. Huang et al. [94] developed porous and well dispersed MnCo2O4 bi-functional electrocatalyst via solvothermal synthesis technique followed by a calcination process for ORR and OER. High performance is because of the porous nanostructure and high surface area and small size of nanoparticles which was controlled by solvothermal technique. 4.1.2 Metal carbides Recently, metal carbides were widely used as catalyst supports for ORR, tungsten carbides (WC) considered the most extensive functional carbide support [95]. Because of the restricted stability of carbide nanomaterials in acidic media and highly oxidizing environments, the application of WC and other carbide nanomaterials as an efficient ORR catalyst appears to be impracticable if the configuration and structure of these materials are not amended. To address these configurations and structure amendments, efforts have been devoted to investigate the outcome of combining Tantalum (Ta) into WC [96]. Improved electrocatalytic performance and stability to the ORR were analyzed in the existence of Ta [97] accredited to the development of a W–Ta alloy. Moreover, Ni-doped Ta–C composite fabricated by sputtering techniques were also observed as ORR electrocatalyst [98]. These prepared materials display higher stability which was ascribed to the formation of a defensive thin film of TaO on the surface of electrocatalyst [99]. 4.1.3 Metal nitrides Transition metal nitrides have attraction due to their good stability in acidic media, so these materials can be deliberated as the potential ORR electrocatalyst [100]. Such as, tungsten nitride supported on carbon (W2N/C) was explored by a single PEMFC system, where remarkable stability was detected [101]. However, the ORR performance of this material was comparatively low, and its significant stability toward ORR extracts it as a favorable non-precious catalyst. Furthermore, Molybdenum nitride nanomaterials were also examined as ORR electrocatalysts [102]. These MoN/C electrocatalyst nanomaterials demonstrated an open circuit potential of over 0.7 V in a single fuel cell system. Especially, the substantial stability of this nanostructured material was measured through 60 h of the procedure. Xia et al. [103] further revealed the catalytic performance of MoN/C electrocatalysts, prepared by the ammonia heat treatment. The effective oxygen reduction by a 4-e− pathway to yield water was ascribed to the hexagonal nanostructure of molybdenum nitride. 4.1.4 Metal oxynitrides Metal oxynitride materials also exhibit specific ORR activity. These types of materials are usually molded by nitrogen doping into metal oxides which can efficiently decrease the high band gap of metal oxides, consequently leads to improved electron conducting properties for electrocatalysis [104]. Furthermore, the integration of carbon into this class of material could also improve their ORR performance [105]. Moreover, researchers reported carbon supported zirconium oxynitride [ZrO x N y /C] electrocatalysts prepared by pyrolyzing ZrO2/C in the existence of NH3 [106]. This electrocatalyst presented an ORR at the potential of 0.7 V versus RHE. Recently, [107] thin films of ZrO x N y produced by reactive sputtering synthesis route exhibited an ORR onset potential of 0.8 V versus RHE. While, In terms of ORR performance, the most promising electrocatalyst nanostructure existing in these types of nanomaterials was found to be in crystalline Zr2ON2phase. 4.1.5 Metal sulfides Xiao et al. reported bread-like FeS with N and S dual-doped mesoporous graphitic carbon as an electrocatalyst for the ORR in alkaline and acidic media [108]. Cao et al. [109] reported nonprecious catalysts for the ORR and OER which have fast kinetics, are very critical to enhancing the proficiency of electrochemical systems for fuel cells. Cobalt sulfide embedded in porous N-doped carbon (NC) was synthesized. Cobalt sulfide/NC nanohybrid displays an admirable ORR performance, which is analogous to that of the commercial Pt/C. Particularly, the OER performance of Cobalt sulfide/NC nanohybrid is higher to that of the RuO2/C. The stabilities of Cobalt sulfide/NC nanohybrid to ORR and OER are considerably enhanced than that of commercial Pt/C and RuO2/C. Li et al. [110] synthesized a novel hybrid material WC/FeS/FePt nanocomposite supported on nitrogen-doped carbon as an ORR electrocatalyst. Because of the attractive numerous encouraging effects from these components, the existing Pt-based catalyst reveals a wonderful mass activity of 317 mA mg−1 Pt at 0.9 V versus RHE, which is 2.5 times higher as compared to Pt/C electrocatalyst (125 mA mg−1 Pt). Furthermore, larger durability in the acidic electrolyte of the WC/FeS/FePt/NC was also revealed. Significantly, this work provides a new approach for the design of high-performance ORR electrocatalysts by integrating the promoting effects of multiple components such as carbides and sulfides. Wang et al. [111] prepared unique hollow nanohybrid structures comprised of well-dispersed electrocatalyst nanoparticles supported in a carbon matrix. Co9S8 and nitrogen doped hollow carbon sphere (Co9S8/NHCS) nanocomposites were synthesized. Electrochemical analyses revealed that the Co9S8/NHCS electrocatalysts synthesized at 900 °C display superior ORR performance, resulting in the highest ORR activity among all the transition metal sulfide-based ORR electrocatalysts. 4.2 Conductive polymer materials Conductive polymers (e.g. polyaniline, polypyrrole, polythiophene, poly(3,4 ethylenedioxythiophene) and poly(3-methyl thiophene)) usually show mixed metal and polymer-like properties and have importance for several applications owing to their low price, characteristic redox properties as well as high electronic conductivity [112–114]. Currently, conductive polymers have been more explored for non-noble metal ORR catalysis in PEMFCs by different techniques: (i) integrating non-noble metal complexes into the conductive polymer matrix, [115–122] (ii) using conductive polymers as catalysts for ORR on their peculiar properties [123,124] (iii) engaging conductive polymers as a nitrogen-carbon precursor material for pyrolyzed carbon-supported transition metal (M–N x /C) catalysts, where (M = Mn, Co, Ni, Fe, etc.) [125–130]. Gabe et al. [131] recently synthesized cobalt oxide nanostructures with multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and explained some key factors for enhanced ORR activity of nanostructured electrocatalyst in alkaline media, higher ORR activity is probably due to the small size of nanoparticles and enlarged interfaces between cobalt oxide and MWCNTs. NaBH4 is added in the synthesis which is essentially required to obtain high performance as it decreases the oxidation states on cobalt oxide as well as the combination of N groups which enhance ORR performance. The key factor is the synergetic effect between the MWCNTs and cobalt oxide nanoparticles. Cai et al. [132] reported non-noble 3D Co-N-doped hollow carbon spheres as a highly efficient bi-functional catalyst for ORR and OER as well as it exhibits good stability. This approach provides a simplistic and energetic method for synthesis of non-noble electrocatalyst with 3D hollow structure. 3D hierarchical N doped carbon flowers which show high ORR performance [133]. Recently CuN complexes have been fascinated for sustainable electrocatalytic ORR. Currently CuN complex on carbon black was investigated for bi-functional electrocatalyst for ORR and hydrazine oxide reaction (HOR) for hydrazine fuel cells. This research provides a novel approach to design efficient non-noble metal electrocatalyst [134]. 4.3 Carbon-based electrocatalyst for ORR In recent times, carbon nanostructures, for example, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), fullerenes, graphite nanoplatelets and graphene sheets, with several unusual molecular structures and optoelectronic properties suggest novel prospects for the improvement of progressive carbon-based electrocatalysts with enhanced ORR activity in PEMFCs [135–137]. Although, CNTs have been fascinated and motivated excessive curiosity for numerous applications besides catalysis, involving in heterogeneous catalysis, hydrogen storage, field emission as well as superconductivity [138–140]. Currently, bamboo-like CNT/Fe3C nanostructure hybrids have been synthesized as improved ORR electrocatalysts. The CNT/Fe3C nanohybrid also displayed much-advanced stability and improved methanol tolerance than commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst in alkaline as well as acidic solutions [141]. This research gives a unique approach to develop novel nitrogen-doped CNT/Fe3C nanohybrid as high-efficiency electrocatalysts for ORR in PEMFCs. CNTs have also been suggested as a substituent for carbon black as another support for FCs catalysts because of their extraordinary properties, large surface area, good electrical conductivity, and corrosion resistance [142–144]. FeNC materials were synthesized and reported by Li et al. [145] The catalytic activities of this synthesized catalysts were evaluated by a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) which demonstrates that the ORR mechanism is thus a 4e− reduction to water in this as-prepared hybrid material. 4.3.1 Functionalized graphene/Heteroatoms doped graphene polymer electrocatalyst Recently, graphene (Gr) has been fascinated because of its distinctive role in electrolyzers, metal-air batteries, and PEMFCs. Gr was used as the alternate support for the Pt [146–150]. Functionalized graphene has been deliberated as one of the upcoming-generation nanofillers because of its comparable physical and chemical properties as well as low-cost fabrication than CNT. The progress of functionalized graphene polymer nanocomposite (FPN) has been increasing in the previous few years. Cai and Song [151] reported most of the literature about FPN's fabrication and properties. Gr is also frequently used as the substitute for carbon black because of its high conductivity, high mechanical strength and high surface area. Monodisperse FePt nanostructures were prepared and effectively deposited on the Gr sheet by a solution phase self-assembly synthesis route and revealed higher specific ORR activities, 5.9–8.8 times higher than typical Pt/C electrocatalyst at the same potential conditions. The FePt/Gr nanostructures were remarkably highly stable than traditional Pt/C [152]. Li et al. [153] reported for the first time, edge-rich and dopant-free graphene as an ORR catalyst. Electrochemical measurements demonstrated that the as-prepared edge-rich graphene displayed tremendous ORR performance through a four-electron pathway as well as, edge-rich carbon nanotubes and graphite can also be found with improved ORR performance. Hence, this research work endorses the imperative role of edge carbon in efficiency of the ORR electrocatalyst. Dou et al. [154] reported highly efficient bi-functional Etched and doped Co9S8/graphene hybrid electrocatalysts for the ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The Co9S8 nanoparticles supported on graphene (denoted as Co9S8/G) by the NH3-plasma treatment, which leads to nitrogen doping into both Co9S8 and graphene as well as partly etch the surface of Co9S8 and graphene. The electrochemical studies demonstrate that the etched and N-doped Co9S8/G displays remarkable ORR performance. In this presented work, a novel and efficient approach is developed to synthesize hybrid bi-functional catalysts for ORR and OER in fuel cells. Fig. 2 shows the schematics of nitrogen doped cobalt sulfide nanoparticles with graphene. Liu et al. [155] fabricated metal-free electrocatalysts for the ORR and OER in fuel cells. In this work, in situ exfoliated, edge-rich, oxygen-functionalized graphene on the surface of carbon fibers efficiently synthesized by Ar plasma treatment. In comparison to pure (carbon cloth) CC, the plasma-etched carbon cloth (P-CC) has a larger specific surface area and more active sites were produced for OER and ORR. Moreover, P-CC exhibits good intrinsic electron conductivity. Theoretical studies demonstrate that P-CC has a low over potential which is comparable to Pt-based electrocatalysts ascribed to the both defects and oxygen doping. This research work conveys a simple and effective synthesis technique for fabricating highly active in situ electrocatalysts on a carbon support. Nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) electrocatalysts might be ascribed to the higher electronegativity of N compared to C atoms, and the consequential positive charge density on the connecting C atoms has been revealed, these aspects might influence on auspicious adsorption of O2 molecules and enhanced the ORR performance. The ORR activity was more improved by doping of nitrogen (Co3O4/N-rGO) by addition of ammonia solution (NH4OH) during the synthesis of nanohybrid. The higher ORR performance of Co3O4/N-rGO relative to Co3O4/rGO was proved by the positive half potential of 0.83 V versus 0.79 V for the Co3O4/rGOnanohybrid, which is analogous to that of typical Pt/C (0.86 V) [156]. Lai et al. [157] presented two different ways to manufacture N-graphene and explained its use as a metal-free electrocatalyst to examine the catalytic active center for the ORR. N-graphene was synthesized by annealing of GO in NH3 or by annealing of N-comprising polymer/RG-O composite. The effects of the N precursors and temperature on the efficiency of the electrocatalyst were explored. The bonding state of the N atom has an important influence on the ORR performance. Annealing of GO with NH3 favorably designed pyridinic N and graphitic N centers, whereas annealing of polyaniline/RG-O and polypyrrole/RG-O have a tendency to create pyrrolic and pyridinic N moieties. Predominantly, the pyridinic N amended the onset potential, while the catalytic performance of the electrocatalyst was found to be reliant on the graphitic N, which evaluates the limiting current. For electrocatalytic applications, chemical manipulation of carbon with other elements is a most effective technique to modify electron-donor properties and for that reason to improve catalytic performance. More recently, numerous novel synthetic techniques [158,159] have been used to reveal a micropore that is analytically very important in accommodating the active sites for ORR in PEMFCs. Nitrogen rich carbon materials generally rely on the synthesis methodology. In the situation to use nitrogen-comprising precursor, for example, melamine or polyacrylonitrile, we can acquire carbon material with lethargic nitrogen composites which change the electronic structure. If the nitrogen is introduced by chemical adaptation of nanocarbon material with nitrogen-consisting reactive elements, such as HNO3, NH3CH4N2O, at that moment nitrogen complexes can be made at the edges and boundaries of graphene structures. The influence of the doping on the electrochemical performance is generally linked with three properties of the dopant: (i) the number of electrons in the outer shell, (ii) the atomic size, (iii) the electronegativity. The widest ranging dopant element is nitrogen as it has a comparable size to carbon and one more electron in the outer most shell than the carbon atom. Nitrogen has four bonding configurations: (i) pyridinic N, (ii) pyrrolic N, (iii) graphitic N and (iv) oxidized pyridinic N. Pyridinic N (N1) and pyrrolic N (N2) atoms are found at edge or defect sites, and graphitic N (N3–N4) atoms exchange carbon atoms in the interior of the structure, whereas Pyridinic N can also exist in its oxidized form represented as (N5) (Fig. 1) [160]. It has been perceived that introduction of nitrogen improves the electron-donor aptitudes of the carbon, thus improves ORR performance [161–164]. The improved activity can be associated with (i) the lone electron pair of pyridinic N and (ii) the existence of additional electrons in the p-orbitals of the carbon framework. The specific comprehensive nature of the active sites in N-doped carbon materials is still a matter of consideration. Various investigators approve that pyridinic N is included in the ORR activity [165,166] whereas others suggest graphitic N [167,168]. However, the recent study proposes that both sites could be equally essential for the ORR performance [169]. Schematics of nitrogen doped graphene given in Fig. 3 . Nitrogen-doped graphene films (N-GFs) prepared via chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method in the existence of ammonia (NH3) have been elaborated to display outstanding ORR performance in alkaline medium [170]. A rationally designed porous nanonetwork electrocatalyst FeNCF developed via electro-spinning for ORR. The transmitted number of electrons was above 3.9 in the potential range from 0.95 V to 0 V, signifying approximately whole reduction of oxygen to water by porous FeNCF network structure, significant performances could be ascribed to the amalgamation of the improved ORR catalytic performance and effective mass transfer of FeNCF [171]. Liang et al. [172] synthesized FeNC catalyst with graphitic shell nanostructures. The obtained electrocatalyst shows high performance towards ORR in acidic and basic media as well as it exhibits high stability and incredible tolerance towards methanol, more over the existence of core graphitic shell nanostructure facilitate the mass transport for ORR between the electrolyte and the catalytic sites [172]. Hence, the synergistic coupling of nanostructures in this research established an auspicious ORR electrocatalyst for PEMFCs. Recently, we reported NiFe2O4 nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-doped graphene (N-Gr) for enhancing ORR performance in PEMFCs relative to pure NiFe2O4 nanoparticles and alone N-Gr [173]. Zhang et al. [174] synthesize flower-like tungsten nitride with nitrogen doped carbon to enhanced ORR performance (Fig. 4 ). The enhanced electrocatalytic activity is ascribed to the double active sites consist of N–C and a unique flower-like WN nanostructures, with a closely 4e− pathway. Consequently, the slow-cost non-noble metal electrocatalyst can be a potential substitute for Pt/C. Heteroatoms doped graphene or carbon has an important influence on the catalytic performance. The ORR activity of doped graphene or carbon has been energetically supported by theoretical studies [175–180]. Researchers reported heteroatom-doped with graphene is a source for ORR in PEMFCs. This work suggests that heteroatom source itself considered as highly performed electrocatalyst [181]. In recent times, Chen et al. proved that the modification in the carbon nanoscale work function is in fact liable for the improvement in the ORR performance [182]. Other heteroatoms such as B, P, and S doped into the carbon materials have also been fascinated for the successful improvement in ORR activity through providing more active sites. Numerous carbon nanohybrids doped with B, P, and S or co-doped with nitrogen had been efficiently prepared and have revealed a significantly enhanced electrocatalytic performance towards the ORR owing to the synergetic effect that arises from the above mentioned doped elements [183–185]. A facile and low-cost synthesis approach have efficiently used to established mass production of BCN-Gr with adjustable N and B-doping levels just by thermal annealing GO in the existence of boric acid under the ammonia gas [186]. Once heteroatoms combined into Gr or CNT, electronic structure reformed and as a consequence active sites will be produced for adsorption of oxygen. Intended for N-doped carbon materials (graphene or carbon), active sites exist at carbon atoms adjacent to the doped N atoms, as the N atoms are highly electronegative polarize adjacent carbon atoms [187-191]. Moreover, the dopants act as active sites for the P or B doped carbon materials owing to feeble electronegativities of P or B atoms [192,193]. For S-doped carbon materials, active sites produced at the zigzag edge spot where doped S atoms exist or adjacent carbon [194]. Jiang et al. [195] reported nitrogen and phosphorus co doped 3-D porous carbon as metal free efficient ORR electrocatalyst by pyrolyzing zero-dimensional C- quantum dots).The as-synthesized NPCN-900 displays extraordinary ORR electrocatalytic performance and strong tolerance to methanol over an extensive pH range of aqueous media. The inspiring ORR activity of NPCN-900 is mainly ascribed to its distinctive 3-D porous structures, rich edge imperfections, large specific surface area and the equivalently amalgamated phosphorus and nitrogen (Fig. 5 ). This research work not only appreciates the modification from 0-D CQDs to 3-D heteroatoms functionalized porous carbon structure, but also demonstrates a facile and template-free synthesis method to achieve excellent catalytic activity and higher stability metal-free ORR electrocatalysts for FCs. Chen reported a novel and facile catalyst N and S co-doped carbon spheres with highly dispersed COO (CoO@NS-CSs) catalyst shows excellent ORR activity. The tremendous ORR activity of CoO@NS-CSs electrocatalyst can be ascribed to its micro-mesopore structure, high specific surface area and highly dispersed CoO [196]. Zhang et al. [197] prepared nitrogen and sulfur doped graphene electrocatalyst with a simple synthesis method by using cysteine as a heteroatom, nitrogen and sulfur source. Excitingly, the cysteine-GO reaction time demonstrates an important impact on the ORR performance of as-synthesized electrocatalyst (Fig. 6 ). The nitrogen and sulfur doped graphene electrocatalyst exhibit superior ORR activity as compared to Pt/C in terms of durability and half-wave potential. Limiting current density and 4e− reduction selectivity is near enough to commercial Pt/C, therefore revealing great promise as a highly proficient ORR catalyst for FCs. Song et al. [198] elaborate the S and N dual doped graphene reaction pathway and competently discussed the synergy effects among dopants. The analysis revealed that there is a chemical adsorption between the SN-G and the oxygen molecule, which is considerably stronger as compared to the individual N or S doped carbon. The synergetic effect is initiated from the enlarged spin density which is generally confined to the sulfur. The chemical bond is not formed between sulfur and nitrogen owing to the much longer distance between S and N (2.55 Å), which is considerably extended as compared to the bond distance in N2S (1.49 Å). The stable structure configuration is evaluated when S and N occupy the ortho sites as displayed in Fig. 7 . 5 FeNC electrocatalysts Hibao et al. [199] synthesized thermally stable 3D mesoporous iron-nitrogen doped carbon electrocatalysts with perfectly ordered mesoporous structural design by hydrothermal route. The acquired mesoporous single nanocrystals are symmetrical rhombic dodecahedral structure, which is precipitately produced by organic-organic accumulation rely on a layer-by-layer growth synthesis mechanism. The existence of open mesopores plays a significant role for feasible transport of ORR associated species and presenting a high content of pyridinic N in the activation of NH3 (Fig. 8 ). The NH3-Fe0.25 N/C-900 electrocatalyst exhibits improved durability and endurance to methanol poisoning as compared to Pt/C. Liu et al. [200] reported preparation of porous carbon supported FeNC electrocatalysts by 6-Chloropyridazin-3-amine, direct pyrolysis of ferric chloride and carbon black (Fig. 9 ). The pyrolysis temperature has strong effects on the ORR efficiency of the as-prepared electrocatalyst. The higher pyrolysis temperature is favorable to the creation of the “N-Fe” sites, but very high temperature causes the decay of nitrogen-comprising active sites. Analyses indicate that FeNC-800 has the best ORR performance. More Interestingly, FeNC-800 electrocatalyst shows improved methanol tolerance and much higher durability than Pt/C in both alkaline and acidic media. Hu et al. [201] reported In situ sulfur doped Fe/N/C (S–Fe/N/C) nonprecious metal electrocatalysts with S doping reaching 4.76 at% by pyrolyzing thiourea as the S source, which shows high-performance ORR activity in both alkaline and acid media. The as-prepared electrocatalyst pyrolyzed at 700 °C displays the excellent ORR performance and also shows much greater durability as well as higher tolerance to methanol than that of commercial Pt/C. Electrochemical measurements demonstrate that the S–Fe/N/C follows 4e pathway in alkaline and acid media. Guo et al. [202] reported a simplistic methodology a direct solid-state template to the scheme of FeN/C-PANI from the transformation of aniline nanopolymer that was used as a single precursor for both N and C atoms (Fig. 10 ). Moreover, the Fe-MMT flat-template can efficiently avoid aniline nanopolymer to form agglomeration in pyrolysis process and more nitrogen-consisting active sites revealed. The synthesized FeN/C-PANI electrocatalyst displayed admirable ORR performance and improved stability in alkaline media as compared to acidic media. Consequently, this research determines that Fe-MMT template-supported transformation of aniline nanopolymer can be a feasible approach to design high-performance FeNC catalysts. Chen et al. [203] prepared FeNC catalysts for ORR via polymerization of aminopyridine organic molecules. The electrocatalysts synthesized through in situ execution of sacrificial support, and also by ex-situ, demonstrate admirable limiting current densities as well as conspicuously high values for half-wave potentials in acidic as well as basic media in RRDE analysis. AMP-resultant electrocatalyst has lowermost peroxide product in 1 M KOH. As polymerization was completed without lethargic carbon, active sites density was estimated to be much higher than traditional synthesis route described on polyaniline-derived PGM-free materials for ORR in FCs. Future strategies to utilized amino aromatic compounds with amino groups to produce 3D high surface area FeNC ORR electrocatalyst for PEMFCs technology. 6 Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)-derived electrocatalysts Initially, MOFs were presented as templates for the preparation of porous carbon material by manufacturing their several cavities and networks [204]. Nowadays researchers reported that MOFs are exist as in-situ molded porous carbon precursors [205–210]. Researchers examined the influence of various porous carbon host material on catalytic performance, enlightening that Zn(II)-based MOF (ZIF-8)-sustained electrocatalyst has 2.6 times higher ORR activity than its black pearls sustained counterparts [211]. The enhanced catalytic performance of ZIF-8-derived electrocatalyst was due to its porous structure with larger surface areas, where micropores act as active sites. Currently, MOFs-based electrocatalysts have significantly risen as a favorable class of ORR electrocatalysts, as MOFs own unusually high surface areas to expose, porous structure, tunable pore size and catalyst morphology, plenty of carbon in the building blocks and organic ligands [212,213]. Recently, MOFs-derived electrocatalysts having core-shell nanostructure such as Fe/Fe3C@C have been synthesized as a very good ORR electrocatalysts. Meanwhile, they effectively control the nanoparticles size and spreading of implanted nanoparticles to enhance the activity; simultaneously, the porous nanostructure and electric conductivity ease the electron and mass transfer [206–214]. MOFs can be classified, such as carboxylic ligands and N-comprising macrocycle ligands [215–217]. Owing to their apparent advantages, studies on the MOFs application to ORR catalysis in PEMFs seems to be successful in previous decades [218,219]. The most widely utilized MOF material in ORR is the zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) [220,221]. ZIF-series materials having tetrahedral nanostructures were revealed for the admirable chemical and thermal stability and everlasting porosity [222,223]. Song et al. [224] reported MOF derived S and N co-doped carbon catalyst for ORR by using ZIF-8 precursor. Results indicate that S and N co-doped nanocarbon displays admirable catalytic performance and stability to ORR in alkaline media than Pt/C (Fig. 11 ). It is found that the high specific surface area and suitable porosity generated in the S and N co-doped carbon, which are advantageous for the mass transportation and ease the ORR as well as coupled dopants stimulate the carbon active sites with higher performance than the isolated S and N doped carbon. The methodology and study revealed in this work proposed strategic attention for designing the efficient ORR. Ye et al. [225] reported surface functionalization of ZIF-8 with ammonium ferric citrate (AFC) directed to segregated FeN active sites produced on the C-AFC©ZIF-8 surface. The performance of C-AFC©ZIF-8 towards ORR and carbon dioxide electro-reduction enhanced with the concentration of isolated FeN active sites. C-AFC©ZIF-8 demonstrates considerable high catalytic activity than C-AFC@ZIF-8 obtained from bulk functionalization of ZIF-8 with ammonium ferric citrate, because of its tremendously exposed iron-nitrogen active sites. Hence, an innovative approach was used to develop immensely exposed and effective FeN restrained within carbon matrix by fastening the active site's material on the ZIF-8 surface. Dou et al. [226] successfully achieved a novel bi-functional catalyst towards ORR and OER, cobalt nanoparticles incorporated in N-doped carbon nanotube (CNT)/porous carbon (PC) by pyrolyzing MOF encapsulated Co3O4. The as-prepared hybrid displayed highly efficient catalytic performance for the ORR and OER. Moreover, it also revealed long-term stability. Fig. 12 illustrates schematic of Cobalt nanoparticle-embedded carbon nanotube/porous carbon hybrid derived from MOF-encapsulated Co3O4. Huang et al. [227] reported for the first time, in situ synthesis of ultrathin MOF nanosheets via a novel bottom-up strategy for 2D metal-based nanoporous carbon electrocatalysts. The as-obtained ZIF-67 nanosheets displayed a uniform morphology and thin structure which have thickness of 4.5 nm. Additionally, due to the highly open structure, high surface area, increased number of available active sites and reduced diffusion blockade, directly carbonized Co, Nitrogen doped porous carbon nanosheets also significantly increase the ORR activity. Especially, the synthesis method specifies that this salt-template confined bottom-up approach can be prolonged to prepare other ultrathin 2D-MOF-nanosheets. Fig. 13 displays the schematics in situ synthesis of ultrathin metal–organic framework nanosheets. 7 Future perspective and research direction In the past years, there has been remarkable development for ORR catalysis. Regardless of higher electrocatalytic performances in activity and durability of Pt-based electrocatalyst, studies on non-noble metal catalysts have also made conspicuous advancement. Recently, novel carbon-based nanostructures have been revealed as substitute ORR electrocatalysts, which could intensely decrease the cost of PEMFCs. Furthermore, the CNTs and dual doped Gr with high physical and chemical properties can also serve as the supports for nanostructures catalysts, which can prevent the relocation and accumulation of the nanostructures and also improve catalytic performance through the synergistic effect in the supports and nanostructures. In current time, it seems very challenging to acquire ORR electrocatalysts with significant performance in acidic media than alkaline media. Therefore, our upcoming research should be further concerned about (1) More development in electrocatalytic performance, particularly in acidic electrolytes, is mandatory, for further fundamental catalytic mechanisms inquiry. (2) To enhance the ORR performance, non-precious metal catalysts with ESA nanostructures could be considered for increasing active sites. (3) There is further need to explore new materials and modify the catalyst preparation techniques and conditions to obtain highly stable and non-noble electrocatalysts which have more active facets. (4) Higher volumetric surface areas and active sites can be obtained by the co-doped carbon supports with the different morphology of nanoparticles and tunable pore size. (5) Fundamental ORR mechanisms and active sites can be discovered by theoretical calculations as well as experimental approaches which assist to design novel catalyst nanostructures. A 5 2017 18610 18617 Maryam Kiani obtained her M.Phil. degree from National University of Science and Technology (NUST) Islamabad, Pakistan. She is currently doing Ph.D. at College of Material Science and Engineering Sichuan University China and doing research on Energy Materials and Devices under supervision of Prof. Ruilin Wang. Her research is focused on non-noble metal electrocatalyst for fuel cells. Jie Zhang received her Ph.D. degree in materials physics and chemistry from Sichuan University in 2017. She is currently a postdoctoral research associate in College of Materials Science and Engineering of Sichuan University for Energy Materials and Devices in the group of Prof. Ruilin Wang. Her main research interest is focused on the non-precious metal electrocatalysts for PEMFC applications. Yan Luo is currently a Ph.D. candidate in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. She received her B.S in Material Chemistry from Sichuan University. Her research interests are focused on the design and synthesis of no-precious electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction under supervision of Prof. Ruilin Wang. Chunping Jiang is currently a lecturer in West China School of Public Health No 4, Sichuan University. She received her Ph.D. degree in Materials Physics and Chemistry at Sichuan University in 2014. She studied in Wyoming University for 2 years as a joint Ph.D. student. Her research interests are focused on water splitting by sunlight, ORR electrocatalyst synthesis and extraction and analysis of Chinese herbs. Jinlong Fan is currently a Ph.D. candidate in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. He received his MS degree in applied chemistry from the Sichuan University of Science and Engineering in 2014. His research interests focus on the refining technology of rare metal and new energy materials. Gang Wang obtained his Ph.D. in Material Physics and Chemistry from Sichuan University in 2014. After postdoctoral research at Sichuan University, he joined the New Energy and New Materials Laboratory at College of Materials Science and Engineering of Sichuan University in 2017 as an associate professor. His current research interests are redox flow batteries related fields. Jinwei Chen is currently an associate professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. He received his Ph.D. degree from College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University in 2010. His research interests are in the areas of nanostructured functional materials and their application in sustainable energy and clean environment technologies. Ruilin Wang is a full professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering at Sichuan University. He received his Ph.D. degree from Department of Chemistry at Bath University in 1999. He worked in Oxford University, Bath University and Imperial College London as a postdoctoral research associate for 4 years. His research interests are in the areas of photoelectrochemistry and electrochemistry related fields.

coredata.dc:description: The main difficulty in the extensive commercial use of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is the use of noble metals such as Pt-based electrocatalyst at the cathode, which is essential to ease the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cells (FCs). To eliminate the high loading of Pt-based electrocatalysts to minimize the cost, extensive study has been carried out over the previous decades on the non-noble metal catalysts. Development in enhancing the ORR performance of FCs is mainly due to the doped carbon materials, Fe and Co-based electrocatalysts, these materials could be considered as probable substitutes for Pt-based catalysts. But the stability of these non-noble metal electrocatalysts is low and the durability of these metals remains unclear. The three basic reasons of instability are: (i) oxidative occurrence by H2O2, (ii) leakage of the metal site and (iii) protonation by probable anion adsorption of the active site. Whereas leakage of the metal site has been almost solved, more work is required to understand and avoid losses from oxidative attack and protonation. The ORR performance such as stability tests are usually run at low current densities and the lifetime is much shorter than desired need. Therefore, improvement in the ORR activity and stability are the key issues of the non-noble metal electrocatalyst. Based on the consequences obtained in this area, numerous future research directions are projected and discussed in this paper. Hence, this review is focused on improvement of stability and durability of the non-noble metal electrocatalyst.
